ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Prof Dvornek is the best! She is so helpful and approachable.
I learned about how MRI machines work, machine learning and image processing, and how to synthesize nanoparticles
I learned about how MRI machines work, how to synthesize and characterize nanoparticles, and how to analyze images with machine learning.
Cell culture, nanoparticle synthesis, rules for using the hood, NMR imaging, reconstructing images
The detailed process and procedure of MRI. Image processing and machine learning. Nanoparticle synthesis and cell interactions.
You developed a strong foundation in NMR. You also get thrown into machine learning and cell culture.
In this class, we learned how to code for image processing as well as how to make and evaluate nanoparticles.
MRI imaging, machine learning, wet lab / nanoparticle synthesis
I learned basic machine learning, how to operate and think about NMR technologies, and how to fabricate nanoparticles.
I learned about NMR Spectroscopy and Imaging, Image Processing/Analysis and Machine Learning, and Biomaterial-cell interactions.
Bettering my BME lab skills that we have learned about in previous courses.
I learned how MRIs worked, how to use matlab for biomedical analysis, and how to produce/analyze nano particles in cell culture.

In this course, I learned about a variety of topics relevant to the biomedical engineering sphere. In the first module, the experiments taught me a lot about the basics of NMR spectroscopy and the science behind technologies such as MRI. In the second module, i learned about the fundamentals of image processing and how images can be manipulated to extract important features. Finally, the last module was my favorite; we learned how to create PLGA nanoparticles and characterize them for drug release, yield, charge, etc.
Learn lots of more in depth lab skills pertaining to biomedical engineering
I learned more about MRI devices operate. I learned how to mathematically and digitally edit biological images. I learned how to synthesize nanoparticle and induce cellular uptake of said particles.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: didn't feel relevant - all labs now program in Python or R but we used Matlab. the procedures felt a bit outdated!

Module 1 (NMR) was not conducive to learning because two groups had to watch on zoom while the third group was in person. The professor was nice for that module and overall, I believe I learned a lot about NMR, but the experience of being on zoom and seeing/hearing/understanding nothing in the moment was not great. Module 2 was fine. Module 3 was pretty fun, except for that fact that sometimes doing a lab with 5 people in the group meant that two people were doing the work and the other three were just sitting around.
I enjoyed how the class was set up as 3 separate modules and the lab report structure of each of them.

Strengths: 3rd module of nanoparticle-cell interactions was very interesting but a bit chaotic given that much of the cell culture was done in not the most sanitary spaces and instructions were a bit vague. 
Weaknesses: Some of the labs were not clear in what the intention was (what we should have gotten out of it)
Every module is so different. I wish there is a more standardized type of module. Each faculty for the modules were helpful in different ways and expected different things for thier module.
The strengths of the course was that the modules were quick so if you didnt like one, you had to wait. A weakness of the course was that the lab reports were sometimes very long.

The first module (NMR) of this class was very disorganized due to the covid requirements which severely hindered learning and made the experience somewhat useless. The second module (MatLab image processing) was very interesting and engaging, but it was too long at times and it was difficult sitting for so long in front of a screen trying to figure out code, so there might be a better way to teach the section. The final section (NPs) was fantastic and there was nothing I would change. A final feedback is that the lab reports were a bit too time consuming and long/tedious so maybe something could be done to address that.

Strengths: hands on learning is the best. You learn so many things you don't even realize along the way. Different modules complement one another well, and the profs and TFs clearly have put time into crafting the course. Great working in groups as well as courses are so often individual.

Weakenesses: lab reports feel manufactured and take a lot of time except for the module 2 in which they are split up. I would suggest making smaller reports due each week in all modules.

Overall, I enjoyed the various modules. I found module 2 to be a source of strength, as I was able to hone my skills in MATLAB. I found module 1 less engaging, however, as we had to do two weeks on zoom.
It was mostly good, I would try to make the first section a bit more engaging for those not in person.

Strengths include the complexity of material, assistance of TAs, working in groups, and detail of procedures. However, the lab reports were long and tedious, with some expectations left vague (second module only).
Strengths: the experiments we performed seemed very relevant and were enjoyable to complete
Really cool being able to do different labs in different groups! The super long lab reports due to only 3 lab reports total over the semester was challenging, but was good overall

The first module wasn't as hands on as I would have liked because we had to split into three groups across three weeks.

The last two modules encouraged students to be independent which I think helped me grow and mature as scientist. I was responsible for following the protocol, understanding it and executing without much assistance from teachers.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, even if you aren't necessarily interested in all three modules, you get a brief overview of three entirely different topics, which is pretty cool.
Definitely a great course (required) of BME students!

Take this course if you have to! It is a good lab if you put the energy in to learn -- gives you a bit of background in a variety of different areas of BME from imaging, cell culture, and image reconstruction (also image-related).
Yes, got the best of three worlds: Real life machine processing and learning, computer based image processing and learning, and cell biology wet lab.
You have to do it if you are BME.
Probably only take if you are a BME major, unless you find nanoparticles or image processing interesting enough to spend four weeks of experiments on and write a very long lab report about.
If you have to take it, that's great! It's a great course. If you don't, I wouldn't encourage you to take a lab class, but as labs go, it's a good one.
It is a required class for the bme major, however it is not too bad.
It is required

I would recommend this course if you want to learn about MRI, matlab, and nanoparticles in a lab setting. The workload wasnt too bad if you work on lab reports every week. The group aspect of the course was especially beneficial, as each member can contribute to overall understanding of content should anyone be confused.

I would definitely recommend this course to biomedical engineering majors. The BME major is often very conceptually-focused, so this lab provided a great opportunity to see how some of the concepts we learned about in the classroom translate practically.
Yes! Especially if you need more basic lab experience to prepare for research, or for your major
Yes, you get hands on experience with much of what you could expect to be working on in a real-world BME setting.
